sequence.notes: Reductive amination of D-glucose with n-butylamine, followed by cyclization to form an N-butyl-morpholine-like derivative (1,2-oxazinane derivative). The product structure drawn in the image, despite being labeled 'Miglustat', is not the actual structure of Miglustat (N-butyl-1-deoxynojirimycin), which is a piperidine derivative. The SMILES provided for the product corresponds to the structure as *drawn* in the screenshot.

An intramolecular cyclization/oxidation reaction transforming an open-chain polyol into a furanose-like ring structure. The product structure as drawn in the screenshot contains a carbon with five bonds (connected to ring-O, ring-C, CH2OH, OH, OH), which is chemically impossible. The provided product SMILES represents a chemically plausible interpretation by assuming one of the two exocyclic OH groups on that carbon is superfluous in the drawing. The stereochemistry at the carbon bearing the N-butyl group (C1 equivalent) appears to invert from reactant to product during the cyclization.
Reductive cyclization of a furanose derivative to form Miglustat (a piperidine derivative).
